course.subject: ECON
course.name: Writing as an Economist
course.description: This course hones students’ ability to “do economics”: to apply economic concepts and reasoning to real-world phenomena,and to express that application clearly and convincingly in writing. In weekly large-class settings, students will work with an economics instructor on interpreting and explaining data, applying economic principles to daily life, building and supporting an argument, and evaluating different perspectives in scholarly debates. In weekly small-group tutorials, a language instructor will lead discussions to analyse texts and workshop individual students’ writing. At the end of the course students will be better prepared to undertake independent research and writing in their economics coursework, as well as to write from an economics perspective for a range of non-academic purposes. For BBA(ECON), BSc(ECOF) and BSc(MAEC) first and additional majors students.
course.prerequisites: (ECON 2103 OR ECON 2113) AND (ECON 2123 OR ECON 3123) AND LABU 2040
course.exclusions: LABU 2020 (prior to 2019-20), LABU 2060

reviews.author: Boeing787
reviews.title: Required course for ECON, ECOF and MAEC from Year 2022-2023
reviews.comment_content:
This is a required course for ECON, ECOF and MAEC from academic year 2022-2023 and beyond. It can be used to satisfy ECON 4670 and LABU 2060 requirements.

Course description: This course aims to help you learn to think and write about economics with greater rigour and clarity, and to improve your ability to apply economic principles and methods to real-world phenomena.

In week 2, you will be asked to identify a meaningful problem from daily life, formulate an hypothesis, evaluate and select information to support your hypothesis, synthesize credible sources and evidence with your own arguments and reasoning, and take account of alternative explanations for, or challenges to your argument.

There are 2 sessions per week: 1 writing workshop and 1 lecture on economic theory. The writing workshop is taught by a CLE staff while the economic part is taught by Sujata. You need to produce a final essay by the end of this course. Note that the final essay constitutes 25% to the final grade. There are many activities and assignments throughout the course that help you write your essay and count towards the final grade.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching quality of this course is good. Sujata is an interesting professor and delivers teaching content in an intriguing way. She puts in effort to make the course interactive and interesting. Professor Hon makes the language component of this course interesting too with many in class discussions and activities.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grades are calculated as follows:
1. Class Participation (10%). Attendance is taken every class so avoid skipping lectures. The professors encourage class participation. Aim to answer question raised by them.

2. Weekly Exercises (10%, graded complete or incomplete). Remember to submit them on time.

3. Short analytical essay (10%). Done in the second to third week of the course, fairly easy.

4. Question, Explanation of Puzzle, and Cribsheet (20%).

5. Outline of final essay (10%)

6. Peer Review of Final Essay Draft and Reflection (15%). A 500 word Peer feedback on a classmate's draft 1000-word essay:economics and language sections.

7. Final Essay (25%)

reviews.comment_workload: There are weekly assignments to complete. These are usually graded as complete and incomplete. Many students complain about the workload of these assignments. However, I feel that if you start early, the workload is acceptable. Completing the final essay is a simple task if you plan ahead, start early and follow the deadlines strictly
